title: Unilateral Conductive Hearing Loss Post-Trauma
chief_complaint: I was shot near my ear about two months ago. Since then, I have a ringing in my left ear and sounds seem muffled, like I am hearing with my head under water.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset approximately 2 months ago following a gunshot wound.
problem_summary.course: Hearing loss has persisted; tinnitus has decreased but is still present.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Tinnitus (ringing), muffled hearing ('under water' sensation). Denies pain and dizziness.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty hearing in the left ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking evaluation of persistent hearing issues following trauma treatment.

history.present_illness: Patient sustained a gunshot wound to the head 2 months prior; bullet entered left cheek near ear and traveled to neck. Noted immediate loud ringing and difficulty hearing in left ear.
history.otologic_history: No history of noise exposure or ear problems prior to the incident.
history.prior_management: Treated for the gunshot wound; now following up on hearing loss.
history.patient_goals: Evaluate persistent hearing loss and tinnitus.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows normal hearing sensitivity (0-10 dB HL). Left ear shows a mild rising to slight conductive hearing loss (250-1000 Hz) sloping to mild/moderate (2000-8000 Hz). Significant air-bone gaps present in the left ear with normal bone conduction thresholds.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Speech Reception Thresholds (SRT) are in agreement with Pure Tone Averages (PTA). Word Recognition Scores (WRS) are excellent/normal bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear normal (Type A). Left ear flat (Type B) suggesting middle ear pathology.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ipsilateral reflexes present. All other conditions (Right Contra, Left Ipsi, Left Contra) are absent or could not be tested (CNT), consistent with left conductive pathology.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing in the right ear and a mild-to-moderate conductive hearing loss in the left ear. Word recognition is excellent bilaterally. Tympanometry indicates normal middle ear function on the right (Type A) and significant middle ear dysfunction on the left (Type B, flat), consistent with the reported 'underwater' sensation. Acoustic reflexes are absent in the left ear and for contralateral stimulation, supporting the presence of a conductive component.
counseling_points: Your hearing test confirms a 'conductive' hearing loss in your left ear, which means sound is being blocked from reaching the inner ear nerve.
The 'underwater' sensation and the flat graph on the pressure test (tympanogram) suggest fluid or an issue with the middle ear space, likely related to the trauma.
The nerve of hearing itself appears healthy, as shown by the bone conduction test and your ability to understand speech clearly when it is made loud enough.
We will refer you to an ENT specialist to examine the middle ear physically; this is often treatable.
notes_for_actor: Portray a young adult who has recovered from a serious trauma (gunshot wound) but is now dealing with the lingering annoyance of hearing loss.
You are not in acute pain, but the 'muffled' sensation is bothersome.
You describe the hearing loss vividly as being 'under water'.
